awd_titl_txt: FOCUS:  Fostering Opportunities for Community, Understanding, and Success in STEM
awd_abstract_narration:
Concordia University at Moorhead will develop Fostering Opportunities for Community, Understanding, and Success (FOCUS), a project that will expand the STEM workforce by developing and implementing strategies that attract, prepare, and retain academically talented, low-income students into STEM careers. Specific objectives of the program are to develop (1) culturally targeted recruiting strategies to attract a broad range of eligible applicants, (2) academic and social support systems focused on retaining students and allowing them to flourish, and (3) vocational experiences that will prepare students for post-graduation success. 

The FOCUS project will develop scalable strategies for recruiting, preparing, and retaining academically talented, low-income students for careers in STEM. Two cohorts of 12 students will be supported by scholarships and integrated high-impact learning practices such as first-year seminars, learning communities, writing-intensive courses, research, and service learning. Students will be supported by academic services, faculty mentors, and peer mentors. Recruiting strategies will be targeted toward talented students from new American families. Professional preparation will highlight four-year career development programs that integrate awareness of opportunities with research positions, job shadowing, professional STEM mentorships, and paid internships. Knowledge-generating activities will address how the integration of high-impact learning practices and other supporting activities affect student success in STEM both at the university and beyond, and the conditions under which such treatments are effective.

por.por_cntn:
With financial NSF S-STEM financial support, Concordia College created a program entitled FOCUS: Fostering Opportunities for Community, Understanding, and Success in STEM. Consistent with the goals of S-STEM, the principal goal of FOCUS was to recruit, retain, and prepare two cohorts of twelve academically talented, low-income students interested in STEM careers. Related to this goal, the specific objectives and related strategies of FOCUS were:

1. Recruit low-income students who show both interest and potential for success in STEM.

  • Recruit two cohorts of 12 students (24 students in total) across all STEM disciplines
  • Diversify our applicant pool with emphasis on recruiting students from new American families in our region

2. Retain these students through financial, academic, and social support.

  • Provide students with significant scholarship support
  • Begin building a cohort through an Orientation Club with leaders who would become peer mentors
  • Enroll students in a first-year seminar course with a focus on metacognitive learning strategies (MCLS) for STEM
  • Build a strong network of connected mentoring support through faculty, staff, and peers
  • Give students early awareness of academic support services and connect them to academic counselors
  • Offer social gatherings and invite students’ families to attend when appropriate

3. Prepare these students for successful and fulfilling STEM careers through vocational guidance and professional opportunities.

  • Offer each student an opportunity to work with a STEM faculty member in a paid research position
  • Provide each student with an opportunity for a paid STEM internship
  • Connect students with career counselors and alumni STEM mentors

Overall, 26 first-year students entered the program in the two cohorts. Of these, 16 (62%) completed the program and graduated with a STEM degree. Additionally, 16 students (62%) participated in undergraduate research with STEM faculty, and 15 (58%) completed a paid STEM internship.

Assessment of program activities led to the following findings:

  • A majority of students found that the overall FOCUS program as well as each of its individual components to be effective.
  • The MCLS seminar was particularly effective in teaching students how to prepare for and take different types of tests, how to add meaning and organization to what they are trying to learn, and how to set higher-level school-related goals.
  • Study journal data suggests that it is not how much a student studied that predicts their achievement, but rather how they studied instead. This further supports the value of offering students designated courses, such as the MCLS seminar, that explicitly train them in the use of effective study strategies.
  • The benefits of the MCLS seminar extended beyond the semester-long duration of the course as the majority of students indicated that they have frequently used the learning strategies learned in the MCLS seminar after the course has ended.
  • The MCLS seminar also helped students form friendships, understand that college courses require a lot more effort than high school courses, develop an appreciation for the scientific method, and understand that there is no shame in seeking help or using the available student support services as needed.
  • FOCUS students felt that the interviews they did with the Career Center staff and the opportunities to chat with professionals in their desired fields were helpful for their career preparedness.
  • Data revealed a pre-post decrease in STEM career interest and motivation. These decreases may reflect the more realistic assessment of oneself that comes with taking STEM courses. On the other hand, there was a pre-post increase in students’ STEM career knowledge and planning, as well as an increase in their STEM self-efficacy.
  • FOCUS students looked up to their peer mentors, appreciated their availability, and felt they can approach them with any questions they have.
  • Research experiences were most effective in increasing communication between STEM faculty and FOCUS students, engagement between students, and student interest in completing a STEM major.
  • Due to the restrictions necessitated by the COVID-19 pandemic, only about half of the students in the FOCUS program met with a STEM mentor. Mentor meetings increased student motivation to complete a STEM major and student sense of belonging to a STEM community.
  • Most FOCUS students engaged in a STEM internship, mostly in their senior year in college. Internships helped students develop a realistic view of the workplace and learn to adapt and be flexible.
  • A majority of STEM faculty attended between two and five DEI developments opportunities. Correlational analyses revealed a statistically significant correlation between the number of events attended and inclusive teaching practices. 

Significant broader impacts of the FOCUS program can be seen through:

  • Dissemination of major results/findings through one published journal article and seven presentations given at national meetings.
  • Continuation of many elements of FOCUS in our new STEM Discovery program established by an endowment gift inspired by FOCUS. STEM Discovery will eventually enroll up to eight new students each year.

 


Last Modified: 05/10/2023
Modified by: Mark B Jensen
por.por_txt_cntn:
With financial NSF S-STEM financial support, Concordia College created a program entitled FOCUS: Fostering Opportunities for Community, Understanding, and Success in STEM. Consistent with the goals of S-STEM, the principal goal of FOCUS was to recruit, retain, and prepare two cohorts of twelve academically talented, low-income students interested in STEM careers. Related to this goal, the specific objectives and related strategies of FOCUS were:

1. Recruit low-income students who show both interest and potential for success in STEM.

Recruit two cohorts of 12 students (24 students in total) across all STEM disciplines
Diversify our applicant pool with emphasis on recruiting students from new American families in our region


2. Retain these students through financial, academic, and social support.

Provide students with significant scholarship support
Begin building a cohort through an Orientation Club with leaders who would become peer mentors
Enroll students in a first-year seminar course with a focus on metacognitive learning strategies (MCLS) for STEM
Build a strong network of connected mentoring support through faculty, staff, and peers
Give students early awareness of academic support services and connect them to academic counselors
Offer social gatherings and invite students’ families to attend when appropriate


3. Prepare these students for successful and fulfilling STEM careers through vocational guidance and professional opportunities.
  

Offer each student an opportunity to work with a STEM faculty member in a paid research position
Provide each student with an opportunity for a paid STEM internship
Connect students with career counselors and alumni STEM mentors


Overall, 26 first-year students entered the program in the two cohorts. Of these, 16 (62%) completed the program and graduated with a STEM degree. Additionally, 16 students (62%) participated in undergraduate research with STEM faculty, and 15 (58%) completed a paid STEM internship.

Assessment of program activities led to the following findings:

A majority of students found that the overall FOCUS program as well as each of its individual components to be effective.
The MCLS seminar was particularly effective in teaching students how to prepare for and take different types of tests, how to add meaning and organization to what they are trying to learn, and how to set higher-level school-related goals.
Study journal data suggests that it is not how much a student studied that predicts their achievement, but rather how they studied instead. This further supports the value of offering students designated courses, such as the MCLS seminar, that explicitly train them in the use of effective study strategies. 
The benefits of the MCLS seminar extended beyond the semester-long duration of the course as the majority of students indicated that they have frequently used the learning strategies learned in the MCLS seminar after the course has ended. 
The MCLS seminar also helped students form friendships, understand that college courses require a lot more effort than high school courses, develop an appreciation for the scientific method, and understand that there is no shame in seeking help or using the available student support services as needed. 
FOCUS students felt that the interviews they did with the Career Center staff and the opportunities to chat with professionals in their desired fields were helpful for their career preparedness. 
Data revealed a pre-post decrease in STEM career interest and motivation. These decreases may reflect the more realistic assessment of oneself that comes with taking STEM courses. On the other hand, there was a pre-post increase in students’ STEM career knowledge and planning, as well as an increase in their STEM self-efficacy. 
FOCUS students looked up to their peer mentors, appreciated their availability, and felt they can approach them with any questions they have. 
Research experiences were most effective in increasing communication between STEM faculty and FOCUS students, engagement between students, and student interest in completing a STEM major.
Due to the restrictions necessitated by the COVID-19 pandemic, only about half of the students in the FOCUS program met with a STEM mentor. Mentor meetings increased student motivation to complete a STEM major and student sense of belonging to a STEM community.
Most FOCUS students engaged in a STEM internship, mostly in their senior year in college. Internships helped students develop a realistic view of the workplace and learn to adapt and be flexible.
A majority of STEM faculty attended between two and five DEI developments opportunities. Correlational analyses revealed a statistically significant correlation between the number of events attended and inclusive teaching practices.  


Significant broader impacts of the FOCUS program can be seen through:

Dissemination of major results/findings through one published journal article and seven presentations given at national meetings.
Continuation of many elements of FOCUS in our new STEM Discovery program established by an endowment gift inspired by FOCUS. STEM Discovery will eventually enroll up to eight new students each year.
